@tcarrcreations The police clarified before @FoxNews' tweet - which didn't mention the French guy - that the Moroccan guy was not a suspect.
@MLKconservative Why don't you take a look at the evidence presented, instead of disregarding things without giving them a fair shake?
@MLKconservative Maybe you actually don't know "liberals" & "libs" that well, because I don't consider myself to be either.

White evangelical Christianity is in decline. Trump tapped into its fear of relinquishing power. https://t.co/PEdXbNshNW HT @DavidTigabu
@robbystarbuck I wanted Obama to nominate someone better & wish he had. But regardless, blocking a vote on him was shameful obstructionism.
@robbystarbuck Only in the sense that they thought they might be able to pull it off. And they did. But the justification is incoherent.
@robbystarbuck Yes, it would also be hypocrisy then. It's hypocrisy no matter how you cut it; these rationalizations are all post hoc.
@eth_KNEES First off, I'm not a "liberal" :). Second, I don't believe in unchecked power for anyone. I believe in a better economic system!
@robbystarbuck The point is that they just spent about a year obstructing a nominee. Complaining about obstruction in response is hypocrisy.
@robbystarbuck Noting that they didn't refuse to allow *every* nominee to the Court over an entire 8-year period isn't a compelling defense.
@randalltrandall No, that's not it! But I would deign to guess that there *is* confusion among those upset about young people's views.
@robbystarbuck That's absurd. "Lame duck" has a very specific meaning that is much, much narrower than over 8 months before an election.
@A2ndEnding Haha, sorry - your tweet makes more sense now :).
Make sure you give @SpawnofGluten props for the awesome question that built on this factoid at the #PelosiTownHall: https://t.co/NQWAtWOTkn
"51 percent of people between the ages of 18 & 29 no longer support the system of capitalism."â€¦ https://t.co/nOSAhLCDVV
Couching these things as views of Democrats, rather than asserting them, makes them seem disputable. They're not. https://t.co/58GI2z86T5
Fact: the @GOP's treatment of Garland was precedent-changing. Also a fact: Their statements now contradict what they did for the past year.
News outlets need to identify hypocrisy as what it is, not make things into "he said, she said" with phrases like "viewed by Democrats."
By the way, this @politico piece is a good example of how *not* to write news articles about political disputes. https://t.co/qU8p7FULbm
@A2ndEnding Some are signaling that they might let Gorsuch through. @OmanReagan
@Mr_Aerospace Oh, he's definitely not (I was very critical of the pick). I'm saying that he's the worst Democrats should accept.

@ScottElliotG Disproving trickle-down is very different than saying tax policy doesn't matter. Anyway, I'm out. Have a good one! @AlanMCole
@ScottElliotG Last thing from me here: That comment is very different than "tax cuts for the rich spur growth," which isn't true. @AlanMCole
@ScottElliotG @AlanMCole I don't have time to get more into all of these things now, but happy to chat some other time.
@ScottElliotG @AlanMCole It cites analyses several others have performed; I'm not sure if the Gale piece was linkedâ€¦ https://t.co/RIAQLHNufV
@ScottElliotG I'll put it on my list, but I'd also recommend you read through the voluminous contradictory evidence we've linked. @AlanMCole
@AlanMCole Nobody denies that some incentives exist; the point is that their effects just don't match supply-siders' predictions.
@AlanMCole Again, I haven't read this paper, but I've looked at a lot of data that should look different if supply-side claims were right.
@AlanMCole Also not familiar with the specifics of Microsoft and Dublin, but a lot of relocations are paper-only, & Dublin is beautiful :).
@AlanMCole Haven't read that particular paper yet, but I'm curious how you explain the consistent lack of basic correlations in the data.
@AlanMCole To the extent you think it's operative, sure. But non-economic incentives matter a lot & the evidence doâ€¦ https://t.co/VpZ6SRog2g
@AlanMCole The same basic theory underlies that prediction; I'd argue that income effects are *far* more likely to be operative for Haves.

I used to work on a project at @EqualityForum where we tried to get FORTUNE 500 companies to voluntarily protect LGBTQ individuals. Many do.
The Employment Nondiscrimination Act doesn't include sexual orientation or gender identity protection & only 21 states currently provide it.
Don't forget that, while nondiscrimination protections exist for LGBTQ federal employees & contractors, other workers don't have them.

@NickKilstein There's a clear implication in what I responded to. It's similar to when people mocked Trump for retweeting a 16-year-old.
@NickKilstein Also, I do think that, in this case, arguing "incompetence!" undermines fighting back (it's basically what Marco Rubio did).
@NickKilstein Experience matters, but that's not the sentiment behind suggesting a 22-year-old can't *help.* @mattyglesias @juliaioffe
@NickKilstein It's ageist. There are plenty of young people who are very good at what they do. @mattyglesias @juliaioffe
@MattBruenig Right; there's nothing wrong with a young person doing things. The problem is what's being done. @mattyglesias @juliaioffe
@mattyglesias @juliaioffe I don't see how "a 22-year-old helped draft them" is a useful critique. The issue is that they're morally wrong.
